title: 8 myths coronavirus second wave
story: But the gradual relaxation of measures could lure some into a  sense of security that could risk a second surge of coronavirus, experts warn.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe World Health Organisation said last week that the worst of the pandemic could still be to come as global deaths passed ,.While scientists know more about Covid- than before the country first went into lockdown, there are still a lot of uncertainties.Alongside that, there are also plenty of misconceptions flying around which could put people at risk.To help keep you safe, weve debunked eight of the common coronavirus myths...While being young and healthy does put you at lower risk of serious illness from coronavirus, it doesnt mean that you wont catch it.Research suggests that most young adults and children experience a very mild form of Covid - or show no symptoms at all.It means that young people are actually at higher risk of spreading the virus to more vulnerable people, potentially without even realising.Some young people may also have underlying health conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic asthma and hypertension, which put them in the at-risk group.But there have been a number of cases in which young people have ended up in hospital or even dying from Covid without having any health issues.Last month, a -day-old baby with no known underlying conditions became Britains youngest coronavirus victim.  The most recent figures from the Office for National Statisticstoday showed that deaths overall in the UK are below normal - and coronavirus fatalities have fallen to the lowest level since before lockdown.But experts warn that while these figures are great news, it doesnt mean the pandemic is over.New positive cases of Covid- had been decreasing as a result of lockdown but this has levelled off in the past few weeks with infections stalling.Deaths tend to lag behind infections as it can take up to two weeks for symptoms to show, experts say.Also, people might not get tested immediately which could lead to a more severe illness and result in hospital care, or ultimately death.Dr. Jonathan Reiner, a professor at George Washington University School of Medicine, told " rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"CNN: It takes about a week after someone becomes infected until they get sick enough to be hospitalised, and then often about a week after that until you start seeing deaths.Boris Johnson said the country had to meet five key tests before lockdown could be eased.These included making sure the rate of infection was decreasing to manageable levels.One of the ways this is tracked is by measuring the R rate - which refers to the average number of people that one infected person can pass the virus on to. If its above one, it will spread exponentially, infecting more and more people.With theR rate below the crucial value of one across the country, the Prime Minister was able to announce that the restrictions could ease further and on July  pubs, restaurants, hotels and hairdressers were allowed to reopen.But some regions, such as the north east, are only just teetering under one, so officials are monitoring the situation carefully.There have also been localised outbreaks such as in Leicester, so the city has been forced back into lockdown to prevent the spread.The Government has warned that it wont hesitate to put other areas under tougher measures - forcing the economy to shutdown again -cases rise.While face masks arent guaranteed to stop someone from catching the virus, they can be helpful in preventing infected people from spreading it.They can stop viral particles from sneezes, coughs and even talking from being released.Currently, Brits have to wear a face mask or covering when using public transport or face being fined.Experts have also advised people to wear one when in places where its harder to socially distance, such as supermarkets.Its not compulsory but some experts are calling on the Government to make face coverings mandatory.Homemade masks wont offer the same level of protection as medical-grade ones, but it hasnt stopped DIY tutorials popping up online.One of the simplest ones involves using two layers of kitchen roll and one tissue cut in half.You then cover each end with masking tape - and you can even tape down some wire to stfen the mask,you have any.Finish by punching holes in each end and threading elastic through to fit around your ears.If you dont have elastic bands you could also use a hair tie.The president of the Royal Society Venki Ramakrishnan said other countries have managed to implement the use of face masks into their daily lives so there was no reason why the UK should not have implemented a more stringent policy.Meanwhile, new research by the Data Evaluation and Learning for Viral Epidemicsgroup said masks could reduce the risk of transmission and can also provide benefits to those who wear them.However, they need to be worn properly - intermittently putting them on and off increases the number of times you touch your face.For the general public, more effective methods of protecting yourself from infection include regularly washing your hands, not touching your face, disinfecting surfaces, and social distancing.Brits have been advised not to purchase surgical coverings due to a shortage or personal protective equipment for NHS workers.The Government has released guides on how to make coverings at home from old t-shirts.If you already have a mask then there is no harm in wearing it, but make sure your mask is sanitised and that your hands are clean when taking it off and putting it on. And wash your hands again after taking it off.Most people who catch coronavirus only show symptoms about five days after being infected - but it can take up to  days in some cases.One study, published in the Lancet, found that during the initial five days - where people reported feeling fine - is when the highest amount of viral shedding happens.This is when infectious particles from the virus spread from one person to another.Experts still dont know how many people are asymptomatic, which is why it is important to self-isolate for  daysyou have knowingly been exposed to the virus.Its also vital to quarantine evenyou dont have the key symptoms of a persistent cough or a fever.The Government recently added a loss of taste or smell to the list of signs that could suggest a mild form of Covid-.Less common symptoms may include myalgia , nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea, soyou feel unwell always contact NHS .With widespread job losses, economic recession and being confined to our homes at the forefront of our mind, its easy to see why this theory crops up.But allowing everyone to become infected with coronavirus - to gain whats known as herd immunity - could have serious negative impacts.A team of scientists at Imperial College London modelled what this would look like in the UK and predicted that it could lead to a quarter of a million deaths that would completely overwhelm the NHS for months.It would also prevent people from accessing healthcare, emergency services and even prescriptions for normal medical reasons, while doctors and nurses are off sick.People could begin dying from minor conditions such as asthma attacks, heart attacks, pregnancy complications, everyday accidents, bacterial infections and more.Experts from " href"https:www.kcl.ac.uk blog-the-ten-most-dangerous-coronavirus-myths-debunked-" target"_blank" rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"Kings College London say that instead of this scenario, governments are aiming to eventually achieve widespread immunity with vaccination - when one becomes available. This way a large part of the population will become immunised in a controlled manner, drastically minimising the devastating potential of the virus.While flu cases decline over the summer, experts dont yet knowthis is what will happen with Covid-.The warmer weather can help as people can spend more time outdoors, where its easier to socially distance.Thats why doctors are concerned about a second wave this winter.But as its a brand new virus, humans havent developed a level of immunity yet, so evenit is seasonal, prevalence may continue to increase as it infects more of the population.Coronavirus spreads via droplets from coughs and sneezes, but you dont necessarily have to be close to the infected person to catch it.It can easily live on a range of surfaces for several days.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.In fact, the US Centres for Disease Control and Preventiondiscovered that Covid- survived on surfaces for  days - after infected passengers disembarked from a cruise ship.So disinfecting surfaces and washing your hands regularly is so vital to stop the spread.An alcohol-based disinfectant is enough to kill the virus on surfaces.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Chancellor Rishi Sunak will use his second financial speech of the year to set out his plans to save the economy from collapse in the wake of Coronavirus.But is he really in a position to do that  The speech - dubbed a aposmini budgetapos - isnapost an official aposfiscal eventapos. Itaposs not a budget or a spring or autumn statement, where the chancellor would usually make sweeping changes to tax and spending measures. But the statement is expected to include a number of boosts for the economy, in a bid to prevent hundreds of thousands of job losses as the governmentaposs furlough scheme comes to an end. Hereaposs whataposs rumoured to be in the chancelloraposs aposmini-budgetapos Everyone gets a £ voucher to spend on the high street Mr Sunak is reportedly considering a £ billion aposhigh street voucherapos scheme. Authors of a report by the Resolution Foundation said vouchers worth £ per adult and £ per child could be handed out to be spent in hard-hit sectors of the economy, such as face-to-face retail, hospitality and leisure. A massive cut in stamp duty Most house buyers will be exempted from paying stamp duty for six months, it has been reported. The property tax threshold could be increased as as high as £, pounds in a bid to exempt most homebuyers from paying any stamp duty and kickstart the economy.  A bonus for companies who employ trainees More than £ million is to be invested in traineeships for - year olds in response to the coronavirus crisis. Businesses offering new traineeships in England will receive a £, bonus per trainee under the £ million scheme.  A aposGreen Homes schemeapos that could help you pay for upgradesHome owners will get £billion of vouchers to insulate homes as part of Chancellor Rishi Sunak ’s plans to create more than , green jobs.Hundreds of thousands of households will get grants of up to £, to make their homes more environmentally friendly. Vouchers worth up to £, will be available to some of the poorest families. The Green Homes Grant scheme — which will provide extra work for plumbers, builders and tradesmen and help the Covid-hit economy recover — will be announced in Wednesdayaposs mini budget. Homeowners will be able to spend the cash on loft, wall and floor insulation, eco-friendly boilers, heat pumps, double or triple-glazed ­windows, low-energy lighting and energy-efficient doors. The scheme will go live in September and, according to Treasury estimates, will save families up to £ a year on energy bills.

story: NewsBrits want to go green but cant afford solar  or electric cars, study findsA poll found seven in ten Brits wish they had more money to buy green items such as solar  and electric cars but they cant afford them, with eight in ten calling on the government to do moreShareCommentsByEmma Elsworthy:,  JUL NewsSolar  are the number one green product Brits want but cant afford ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMillions of Brits are unable to go green - because they canapost afford it, a study has found. A poll of , adults found  per cent donapost feel they can make any eco-friendly changes to their current lestyle, because their bank balance wonapost allow it. The average person has just £ disposable income per month, but seven in  wish they had more to allow them to live a greener lestyle. Organic food, electric cars, energy-saving bulbs and double glazing are just some of the aposgreen itemsapos Brits would love to buy, but simply canapost afford. And as many as eight in  adults say the government should do more to incentivise home owners to help save the planet. Claire Tracey, Chief Strategy  Sustainability Officer for Nationwide Building Society which carried out the study said: Financial constraints shouldnapost hold people back from being able to be more eco-friendly. We welcome the Government making up to £k available to homeowners to retrofit their homes. Our study shows that many consumers who want to go green are prevented from doing so by the price of ethical and sustainable products. This new incentive is therefore a helpful start to making the UKaposs homes greener. At Nationwide, we want to help our  million members reduce the carbon footprints of their homes, whether they own or rent them. Greening our homes for future generations is a joint effort between the public, the Government and lenders like us. As we green our economy, it is critically important to make it work for everyone. The study also found almost half of those polled would love to be able to install solar  into their home, while a third would buy an environmentally-friendly laptopmoney allowed. A quarter would like to have organic towels and bedding, while other small purchases such as eco-friendly dishwasher tablets, compostable bin liners and recycled toilet paper are wanted but off-limits due to the cost. Brits would also like to install low-flow shower heads , purchase a solar powered lawn mowerand have solar powered charging stations for gadgets- but canapost afford to splash out on such aposluxuriesapos. It emerged six in  adults wish they had enough money to make signicant changes to their home that would help the planet, with the average adult estimating theyaposd need to fork out an additional £ a month to make a dference. Other barriers stopping Brits from going green include an unwillingness to changeand not really understanding how to alter behaviour . But the cost of goods is the overwhelming factor, with  per cent saying the price of buying locally and ethically is unobtainable for many. The study, carried out via Onepoll, found there is a general willingness among  per cent of adults to try and help the planet, when money allows. More than half of Brits will walk rather than drive at any given opportunity, and a third are making a conscious effort to eat less meat. Taking reusable carrier bags shopping has become the norm for  per cent of adults, while two-thirds try to recycle when they can. And just under half of those polled try to turn off all household technology when not using. Other methods commonly adopted include avoiding buying plastic when possible, having a compost bin and getting the food shopping delivered. But sadly,  per cent would definitely make more effort to be eco-friendlyit didnapost cost so much money, and  per cent are worried how their current shopping choices might impact the environment and future of the planet. Nationwide already offers a Green Additional Borrowing mortgage which has cheaper rates in order to fund improvements such as better insulation, new windows, solar  and even electric car charging stations.

Jordan Tye, , arrived in Lleida in the northeastern Catalonia region on Friday for work - but he warned other Brits I would stay away from Spain. He described the city as like a ghost town and was shocked by how it changed from one day to the next.Police at roadblocks began warning drivers they were entering a lockdown zone on Saturday as Spainaposs northeastern region of Catalonia reimposed restrictions on more than , people following several new coronavirus outbreaks.Residents in Segria, which includes the city of Lleida, are not allowed to leave the area, although they will not have to stay at home as was the case during Spainaposs original lockdown. Mr Tye, from Leeds in West Yorkshire, toldon Monday: The whole of Lleida is blocked off by police - the main roads and even the small roads. If you are in Lleida you canapost exit andyou are outside you canapost enter. I got into Lleida a couple of days ago. The first day the city was full of people and we went out for meals. Then yesterday it was like a ghost town. Everything looked shut when I was walking around, shutters were down, police were everywhere. All you can hear are ambulance sirens. Last night there was not a soul on the streets.  He continued: Spain is not a nice place to be in at the moment. Itaposs mega expensive, thereaposs not much public transport. Youaposve got to wear face masks and gloves everywhere. Itaposs a nightmare. I wouldnapost advise anyone to come to Spain, I would stay away. As soon as Iaposm done here Iaposll be on a flight back home. He said it reminds him of how the UK was during its aposworstapos time in the pandemic.Mr Tye, an installations manager for an engineering company who travels all around Europe, has an authorisation letter to travel from his company - meaning he is exempt from the rules. But he saidheaposd have known what the situation in the region would be like he would absolutely not have gone. Mr Tye, who spent a few days in Barcelona last week, is due to spend another two weeks in Lleida but is planning on moving hotels to stay outside of the exclusion zone. Weaposve decided to confine Segria due to data that confirm too signicant a growth in the number of Covid- infections, Catalan regional president Quim Torra told a news conference. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFoxes are beaten, skinned and chucked on a heap before their fur is made into coats to be sold on the high street. Aerial images of a farm in Asia show thousands of the animals strewn across the floor – some still alive – waiting to be carted off on the back of a lorry. TV wildle presenter and campaigner Chris Packham described it as “like a scene from hell” and one of the worst cases of animal cruelty he has witnessed. More than  million animals are killed each year for their fur including mink, fox, raccoon dog, chinchilla and rabbit – three every second. They typically spend their lives in one-metre-squared battery cages and are only moved twice – for weaning and on the day they die. Since a  fur farming ban in the UK, pelts worth £million have been imported. Much of the fur comes from China, the US, France, Italy and Poland. In  almost £m of animal fur was imported, including £.m from China alone. Today the Daily Mirror is calling for an immediate ban on the sale of fur products in the UK. Joining forces with Humane Society International UK, we also want an end to animals being trapped for their skins here, and repercussions for businesses knowingly passing off real fur as fake. The footage was captured by the charity’s investigators. The exact location has not been revealed to protect their identity for fear of punishment. One of the team said: “I’ve never seen so much death in one place. It really shocked me and I had to steady myself to keep filming. “There was a mountain of dead bodies, there must have been  tens of thousands of animals discarded like rubbish, like their lives meant nothing.”  He also captured animals repetitively pacing and swaying their heads, classic signs of mental distress and boredom. Animals are kept in rows of cages in long sheds exposed to the elements. Cages are barren apart from the faeces on the floor. Water dishes were also empty. But that is the least of their problems. When the foxes and raccoon dogs are a year old and their winter coats have developed, they are repeatedly smashed over the head with a metal bar while terried cage mates helplessly bark. Investigators also captured what experts say is strong evidence of a fox regaining consciousness after being fully skinned and thrown on a pile.  HSI UK veterinary consultant Professor Alastair MacMillan said: “The pain of that would be unimaginable. This footage is absolutely appalling. The stunning and slaughtering process is done with such a flagrant lack of skill or care, making it highly likely that many of these foxes did not lose consciousness and suffered severe pain. “Equally, a signicant proportion could have regained consciousness before, during and even after they had been skinned.” Packham gave his backing to the sales ban campaign, saying: “I am astonished at the depravity of the fur trade. It is like a scene from hell and anyone who knowingly wears fur should not turn away from watching it. Aside from the unbelievable cruelty of their deaths, these foxes and raccoon dogs will have endured utterly miserable lives. “There can be no place in British shops and wardrobes for fur, not when this is the price animals pay.”  The world’s total fur sales in  totalled £.billion, according to the Fur Information Council of America. Some fur creations were seen on the catwalks at Milan Fashion Week this year but designers including Prada, Gucci, Armani, Versace, Michael Kors, Jimmy Choo, DKNY, Burberry and Chanel have ditched it. In , Calornia became the first US state to ban fur sales. This year, Hawaii and Rhode Island followed. Many British retailers are actively fur-free but clothes, shoes and accessories made of fur can still be found on the high street and online – whether the buyer knows it or not. A Daily Mirror investigation found real fur clothes masquerading as fake, made from the pelts of foxes, rabbits and raccoon dogs, from as little as £ in shopping centres and markets.  It is estimated % of China’s wildle trade is dedicated to fur production, making it the world’s biggest.In the Netherlands,  mink fur farms have been closed down after animals were confirmed as infected with the coronavirus strain that causes Covid-. More than , mink were culled by government order.Three farms in Denmark infected with the coronavirus are also shut. Claire Bass, executive director of Humane Society International UK said: “Behind the PR spin of the fur trade, this is the hideous, heartless reality they don’t want you to see.  “Raccoon dogs driven mad with boredom in their pitully small wire cages, foxes repeatedly smashed over the head with a metal bar in front of their terried cage mates, animals skinned alive so that the fur trade can sell consumers the lie of luxury. “I am sickened and heartbroken by what our investigators witnessed on these cruel farms, but not surprised.“Every designer putting fur on the catwalk, every retailer putting fur on its shop shelves, and everyconsumer putting fur in their wardrobe, is helping to pay for this shameful misery.“It needs to stop, and the UK is now in a unique position to take action by banning fur sales.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA tourist claims to have been living in an airportaposs deserted departure area for  days due to the coronavirus pandemic. Roman Trofimov says he has been stranded in the Philippines during lockdown after getting stuck on a dream trip to southeast Asia. In a bizarre saga reminiscent of the Tom Hanks film The Terminal, the Estonian national claims to have been eating and sleeping in Manila airport for months and washing in the bathrooms. He is pleading to be rescued from the airport, where he has been in limbo since he arrived on an AirAsia flight from Bangkok on March . Mr Trofimov can be seen sporting a long beard and shaggy hair in viral Facebook posts documenting his plight - in which he claims to be surviving on food and snacks donated by airport staff. He shared pictures of his aposmealsapos of bottled water and chocolate bars on social media, claiming he has been told he must stay put until local quarantine rules change as he begs for help. The stranded tourist claims the airport is like a ghost-town - with staff rarely to be seen, and most flights grounded. Mr Trofimov claims he had to sleep on the terminalaposs floor and on metal benches at first.  Eventually the Estonian consulate stepped in to help him be transferred to the passenger lounge on April , he said. According to ERR media he hails from the eastern Estonian town of Jõhvi. He first arrived in southeast Asia via Thailand, in a transfer from Novosibirsk, Russia. According to his series of Facebook posts, Mr Trofimov claims he saved up a year for the dream trip.  He was travelling in Southeast Asia when coronavirus lockdowns began kicking in, and he claims his passport was taken before going through immigration. The airline he flew in on was also unable tohim to Thailand as flights around the world were being grounded due to fears over the deadly virus.  He claims he was then denied entry into the Philippines due to entry visas no longer being issued for arrivals as Covid- began ramping up its march around the globe. Mr Trofimov was among travellers around the world caught up in the chaos as airlines halted travel and countries rush to close their borders.  While most tourists stranded managed to jet home on last-minute flights or were repatriated by their governments, Mr Trofimov claims to have been struck ever since. His plight is eerily similar to the plot of the -comedy Terminal, in which Hanksapos character Viktor Narovski is stuck in New Yorkaposs John F. Kennedy Airport terminal for months due to a military coup in his home country, an Eastern European state that is never named. Mr Trofimov likened his own situation to being a prisoner.  Documenting his plight, he said: aposaposIaposve been stuck here for more than  days. I need help getting out. The airline said I need to wait for Enhanced Community Quarantine to be over before I am allowed to fly. Iaposve been waiting here ever since.aposapos Mr Trofimov claimed he had an onward flight to Cebu province booked for the same day on March  and aflight to Bangkok for April . But both were cancelled.  The desperate tourist said he had asked his embassy for help but they were unable to organise a repatriation flight. Coronavirus restrictions have been implemented in the Philippines according to the risk level of each region. TheManila, where the airport is located, was under the Enhanced Community Quarantinefor a few months before it shted to a lower level General Community Quarantine in June. However, despite having a more relaxed guideline under the GCQ status, most flights are still not allowed to resume - including to Estonia.  Mr Trofimov, who has a bad back, added: I am a person with disability, my health is getting worse because of malnutrition, lack of sun, and fresh air. I have no other choice, but to go public please share with news agencies. According to ERR, Mr Trofimov explained he had been hoping to travel in southeast Asia for months before he got stuck. He said: This was my dream. I compared both Thailand and the Philippines and couldnapost decide which country would be better to travel to for months to free myself of stress and the hustle and bustle of the city that my nerves couldnapost take anymore.  The Ministry of Foreign Affairs told Estonian media it is aware of Trofimovaposs situation and is looking for a way tohim home. The ministry told ERR they were made aware of Trofimovaposs situation on March , when the man had reached Manila Airport, where he was not allowed further entry to the country due to travel restrictions. Estonian officials told news site ERR it is trying to help Trofimov organise a flight after he initially declined toto Estonia, but has since expressed a desire toto country.

title: dca looks ahead to reopening its doors
story: Staff at Dundee Contemporary Arts have said they are planning to reopen their doors to the public in September.After closing its doors back in March because of the coronavirus outbreak, the popular DCA now says it will be officially welcoming people back on Friday, September .This will include the cinema, cafe, bar and print studio, with the galleries set to open a week later.Beth Bate, director of DCA, said: “After this long closure period we are incredibly excited at the prospect of welcoming audiences back into our building.“We have heard from so many people who miss being able to visit and we have missed seeing our audiences just as much.“Our focus now is on ensuring that we have the right measures in place to offer the safest, most enjoyable experience possible when we open our doors, all in line with the latest government and sector advice.“We are making plans for comprehensive training for our team, rigorous cleaning schedules and changes to capacity and scheduling.“We have arrived at our date for reopening based on these plans, having identied it as the earlier point at which it will be safe and effective for us to do so.“We must also acknowledge the fact that we face many challenges on reopening.“With costly new safety measures and reduced capacities throughout the building, we need to raise additional funds to sustain our work.“Our ticket prices will remain the same, but we are asking for donations from anyone who is able to support us.“We will continue to share updates about our reopening plans over the coming weeks, and can’t wait to see our staff, audiences and partners back in the building soon.”Beth says until they are able to reopen in September, the team at DCA will be running online activities and community outreach events throughout the summer.She continued: “In the meantime we will continue to offer as much of our programme as possible online – our film club and quiz, Exhibitions reading group, Monday Makes and Discovery Shorts have all been hugely popular during this time and we hope audiences will continue to enjoy them over the coming weeks.“We will also continue the work that we’ve been doing in communities during lockdown.“We have been making family art bags for groups and organisations including Dundee International Women’s Centre and Advocating Together, and we’re currently taking part in Children’s Art Week, creating themed activities that will be included in packs from the Maxwell Centre.“We are inviting audiences to share their creative projects with us while we’re still closed.“We’d like children to send us artworks and writing to include in wellbeing bags for Dundee Pensioners Forum, which will be sent to older people who are on their own.“And we’re asking anyone who has been busy making during lockdown – whether that’s crafting, painting, printing or baking – to send us a photo so we can share it and celebrate the creativity that has flourished across Dundee and beyond despite the challenges of the past few months.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited title: full back tom field leaves dundee
story: Left-back Tom Field has left Dundee after playing just  minutes of football since arriving in January.The -year-old was snapped up in a late deadline day deal in the winter after the club were hit by news of first-choice full-back Jordan Marshall’s injury.Marshall was ruled out for months with a severe thigh injury late in the window, prompting manager James McPake to move for Brentford’s Field, a player previously on the club’s radar.However, a change of formation shortly after his arrival in February saw winger Declan McDaid excel at left wing-back leaving former Irish youth international Field on the bench.He did make his Dark Blues bow at the start of March, playing the final  minutes as a substitute in a - draw at Ayr United.That was the extent of the action for the former Brentford player, though, as Dundee’s continued good form and defensive solidity before the lockdown made it dficult to get a place in the team.That and a curtailed season thanks to the coronavirus pandemic saw Field barely kick a ball for the Dark Blues in his six months at the club before his short-term deal finished.Also leaving the club is youngster Grant Rodger after the defender’s youth contract came to an end.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: north east farm shop owner looks back at scheme that fed dozens of children
story: The owner of a north-east farm shop providing daily lunches for dozens of local children has thanked the people who helped her keep the scheme running.Michelle Clark, who runs the Kemnay Farm Shop, estimates she and her team fed - kids in the town every day for  weeks.The initiative has now come to an end, with a big barbecue held on Friday to mark the occasion – treating  children to burgers and ice-cream.Michelle, , admitted she had no idea the scheme was going to last as long as it did when she started it in March.And the project even drew the attention of the Duchess of York, who donated £, to the farm shop as well as providing recipe packs and treats of shortbread and yoghurt.Michelle said: “It was something I saw on Facebook, and I thought that’s something I could do as well, and it would make such a dference to these kids.“But I can’t believe how much of a dference it’s made.“The amount of people that have got in touch with me to say it’s really helped them get through the lockdown, it#s been part of their lockdown routine, they could walk to the farm shop and get their lunch.”She added: “It’s a lot of credit to a lot of people, and especially to Leigh Barker and Shirley Dow. They’re the girls who are in the shop most of the time.“Leigh came to us when the schools stopped, because she was a school cook, and she’s been doing most of the cooking for the kids as well.”Jill Thomson, , a furloughed major emergency management instructor for Petrovac from Craigearn, was one of the volunteers who helped to keep the Kemnay kids fed.She said: “I’ve admired Michelle and her team, and how hard they’ve worked over the entire lockdown period. I’m glad to be a small part of it.“If it wasn’t for Michelle and her tribe of girls this would never have happened.”As well as donating money, the Duchess of York also dedicated a story reading session on her YouTube channel to children at primary schools in the area.A spokesman for the Duchess said: “The Duchess is so happy to be able to carry on helping with what she hopes have been delicious school meals for all the children.“She knows what a tough time it is for many people and is delighted to do her bit.“As before, she hopes the children have also been watching and enjoying her storytime with Fergie and Friends every day on YouTube and reminds them that things will eventually get back to normal.”Jill said: “The Duchess’s generosity has really touched the heart of Kemnay community.”Looking back at the impact of the scheme, Michelle said: “I am so grateful to the girls who worked for me, they are absolute superstars and I could never have done this without them.“Louise , one of our volunteers, has made every delivery every day since we started. She’s been a superstar as well.“I’ll miss the kids, actually. We’ve really got to know a lot of them, and they come in just beaming, and we get little cards brought in or boxes of chocolates, or just pictures they’ve coloured in for us.“I’ll miss them, although I’m sure they’ll continue to come in and see me.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: children under 12 could be the first aberdeen fans to return to pittodrie
story: Children under the age of  could be the first Aberdeen fans toto Pittodrie when the Scottish Premiership resumes.The requirement for children aged  and under in Scotland to observe social distancing was removed last Friday and there is no limit to how many dferent groups they can meet in a day.It has led to some calls for schoolchildren to be handed the chance to help fill SPFL stadiums when Scottish football s next month.Scotland’s national clinical director Jason Leitch said it was “an excellent idea” that was worth exploring and Aberdeen FC are also keen to ascertainit would be possible.The Dons are set to begin their   Scottish Premiership campaign with a home match against Rangers on August .A spokeswoman for Aberdeen Football Club said: “We’d be keen to consider how this could work, in line with government guidance. We’d need to look carefully at the safety and supervision of the youngsters, but it could be a great opportunity for our younger fans.“If it’s feasible, priority would be given to our under- season ticket holders and our AberDNA Junior members.“We launched AberDNA Junior earlier this year to offer free membership to every child under  across the region with almost , already signed up. We had planned a signing on day at Pittodrie for these new, young members but this has been postponed due to lockdown.“Having these new, young fans into the stadium, perhaps earlier than other fans, would be a fantastic way for them to start their Dons journey.”When asked about the possibility of children being allowed into football grounds, Prof Leitch said: “When we get to crowds I think there may well be a thought that classes could go or school trips could.“I think that’s an excellent idea. The extra bit we’d need is the ability to gather in large groups outdoors, particularly for adults.“That will come in time.“I think the idea is a neat transition to actual crowds, physically distancing. I don’t think it’s a stupid idea.“It’s certainly worth exploring, but we are not there yet.“One of the challenges of schools going back on August  would be transportation. So we’re going to have to solve those problems.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: plans in place for 2021 camanachd cup final
story: Fiona ScottUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsFollowing the expected cancellation of shinty’s  cup competitions, the Camanachd Association has confirmed with title sponsor Tulloch Homes and Kingussie Camanachd Club that the plan to host the final in Kingussie will be postponed for a year and will now take place on September  .The Tulloch Homes Camanachd Cup Final willto the Highland venue for the first time since  and for its th anniversary.First contested in , the final of shinty’s national knock-out cup competition promises to be a brilliant day out for all the family and a  chance to watch two of the country’s elite shinty teams.Hundreds of tickets have already been sold and to be part of this historic moment you can secure your tickets, including some exclusive offers, on shinty.The  final takes place at The Dell and will be one of the biggest stagings of the event in its -year history with live traditional music, entertainment and a dedicated Kids Zone adding to the festival feel.The first final of the Camanachd Cup took place at Inverness on April  . Great interest was centred on the match, played at Needlefield, a piece of ground situated between Longman Road and Cromwell#s Fort, which was described as being #in good condition for the game#.The contending teams were Kingussie and Glasgow Cowal, two brilliant exponents of the game. The day was practically observed as a holiday in Kingussie and the special train which conveyed the team to Inverness brought more than  people to see the contest. From strath and glen, ardent enthusiasts are said to have flocked into the city, the streets of which contained wearers of kilt and knickerbocker galore.Entrance was a shilling and there were around , present. Gate receipts amounted to £. As the teams lined up on the field, the crowd anxiously weighed up their physical abilities.At the end of the day, Kingussie emerged victorious winning the championship by two hails # as they were then described # to Cowal’s .News of the victory of the home team was received with much satisfaction in Kingussie and district and the players were accorded an ovation on their , met by pipers and others carrying lighten torches, assembling at the station, and marching through the town, while bonfires were lit above the burgh and two on the farm of Dunachton.Gates for next year#s final will open at am on the day with the rising stars of shinty contesting the MacMaster Cup U final before the throw-up for the main event in the afternoon.The Tulloch Homes Camanachd Cup Final attracts thousands of spectators on the day and is also broadcast live by BBC Scotland across television, radio and online s.To buy your ticket contact your local club or buy online via www.shinty. For further information call  .

title: letters to the editor june 5 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Thank you for publishing the informative article in your May  edition about the ongoing consultation for the old Kilmartin church building, which runs to June .We would like to remind readers, particularly those who live in Slockavullin, Ford, Bridgend and Kilmichael Glassary and all the homes in between, that the consultation is for everyone who lives in the Dunadd area.So please share your views # http:dunadd.scot church  and then click #Register Your Opinion#.Gary Linstead, Dunadd Community Enterprise.Sir,Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarked its seventh anniversary on May .I look back with pride and gratitude on a service that has saved and improved thousands of lives and on the organisations, communities, businesses and iniduals across Scotland who helped launch and sustain that service.None of us could have foreseen the situation we find ourselves in, as we reach this landmark seventh birthday. This is a challenging operational environment for our aircrew and an extremely dficult period for our fundraising teams as the restrictions are preventing all the events, talks and activities taking place which are so essential to help support the country#s only charity-funded helicopter air ambulance service.It costs around £ million each year to fund our Perth and Aberdeen-based helicopter air ambulances. Every penny needed to keep these two lesavers in the air seven days a week,  days a year, is donated by the people of Scotland. We receive no statutory government funding.Yet, as I reflect on how the Scottish public has risen to every request we have made of them over the past seven years, I feel confident they will not abandon #The People#s Helicopter# at this particular time of need.Please support SCAAyou can and help us celebrate the seventh anniversary of this lesaving service # your service.John Bullough, Chairman, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance, Perth Airport.Sir,Volunteers are always important. But in challenging times, when our communities need them most, they are invaluable.During Volunteers# Week # June  to June  # I am so proud of the Scout volunteers in Scotland. Together they are helping tens of thousands of young people gain skills for le # helping them speak up, play their part and find their place in the world.To keep everyone safe, Scouts aren#t able to meet face to face. But this hasn#t stopped our volunteers from supporting young people. So many of our brilliant leaders are still running meetings online, helping Scouts catch up with their friends and continue to earn their awards.At a time when our children#s lives are so badly disrupted, these sessions are providing a sense of normality and continuity that#s so important for their well-being. We have also been supporting families across Scotland and beyond with free resources at scouts.org.uk the-great-indoors.I#d like to say a huge thank you to all our volunteers, whether you drive the minibus, make the drinks, look after the accounts or help deliver vital skills for le. We couldn’t do it without you. Your kindness and resilience in these tough times is inspiring and is making a dference.Andrew Sharkey, chief commissioner, Scouts ScotlandAlison Macdonald replied: #Lockdown has made me realise I took the little things for granted, being able to visit family and friends whenever I like, going out for lunch, celebrating occasions and just being able to go for a drive because I can. But seeing how our wee community comes together in times of need is always inspiring. Everything from businesses volunteers adapting to supply frontline workers with much-needed supplies, to people volunteering to collect shopping and essentials for people shielding. It#s made me realise community spirit is still very much alive in Lochgilphead and all over Mid Argyll.#Belinda Braithwaite posted: #That I can find joy in small things such as the birds and connections with friends and the community. And that nature didn’t know we were in lockdown and spring sprung into le.#Duncan Black said: #What it#s made me realise is just how many people evidently long to be in Stasi-esque organisations and just how easily tyranny can be implemented under the excuse of fear or political pandering.#Fyonna Doe responded: #Not to take anything for granted, especially seeing my family and friends, going for lunches, getting my hair done # everyday things that were the norm until the lockdown.#Niamh Rodden posted: #To not take anyone or anything for granted, especially seeing family and friends. It never seemed like a big deal till now when you aren#t able to do so, especially when you have small children and grandparents are missing out on so much. But we are all keeping each other safe. Stay home unless it#s completely necessary, stay safe and hopefully the day we get to see family again won’t be far away.#Karen Pickering said: #That people do care. I never realised how much I took seeing family and friends for granted until now.#Morag Macdonald replied: #My home is my safe place and I would be in a mess without the care of my husband. How much I miss my family and how I need to hug them.#Cathie Wilson responded: #I miss my family and I can honestly put up with hubbys weird singing noises!#

title: mid argyll youth footballers show promise in strong league
story: Bruce WestUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThis was the Lochgilphead youngsters# fourth season playing -aside football.After two seasons in the Dumbarton League, finishing second then first in the league and winning the league cup both years, the boys moved to the Glasgow League in - finishing in the top half of a very competitive Division A and making it to the final of the league cup.Another competitive season was anticipated with five new teams joining the A Division.The season started well, with Star winning all three of their league cup group games against Cambuslang Reds, Cumbernauld Colts and Glasgow Red Star -, - and -.With Cambuslang Reds and Cumbernauld Colts being new opponents this was a good start and Star qualied for the knockout stages. But the COVID- lockdown interrupted proceedings.This season’s Scottish Cup was a bit of a disappointment with Star exiting the competition in the second round after losing out to a vastly improved Dumbarton United side -. On the plus side, the first round saw Star take on Paisley League team Pollok FC and an excellent performance saw Star run out convincing winners -, one of only four defeats suffered by Pollok in all competitions.In the West Region Cup, Star progressed to the quarter-final again. A first round bye, a convincing - win against Cambuslang FA then a walkover saw the Lochgilphead youths face Paisley League A Division team Erskine.In a hard-fought encounter, Star matched Erskine for most of the game but with only  players available they couldn’t get the breakthrough they needed and eventually lost -.Star started their league campaign in September with a competitive match against new team Thorn, who transferred from Paisley A Division. Star lost -.Two strong performances in October saw Star record  a terric - win over Shettleston, last season’s league runners up, and a - win against St Patrick’s Sports Academy # an entertaining but nerve-wracking game.A mid-season stutter in November saw the Lochgilphead boys lose out to Cathcart -, then Clydebank -, both newcomers.The losing run continued into early December as Star faced last season’s champions Drumchapel Amateurs ending up down - at half-time before recovering their form with a committed second half display to pull it back to -. Unfortunately they lost out to a fourth Drumchapel goal as they chased the winner themselves.This set Star back on track as they finished the year with a hugely convincing performance, demolishing Cathcart -.January and February proved a real battle with the weather with wind, rain and freezing temperatures # often all three # only allowing four games to take place. Star secured fine victories over Busby, -, and Glasgow Red Star, -, and fought back to grind out creditable draws with Shettleston, -, and Place Park, another new team, -.Star played one league game in March before lockdown and again it was another entertaining game with a rollercoaster feel to it. Facing up to Drumchapel Amateurs, both teams played out another terric match which had everything.Coming back from a goal down and with only  men, Star played cracking football to race into a - lead but it took its toll as Drumchapel stuck to their task to draw level before adding a couple more goals to secure a win in the final five minutes.This was another fine season for Red Star s, competing well in a strong league, with only  signed players.Though the season was cut short, the boys played  games winning , drawing two and losing seven. They scored  goals and conceded  goals. There were some cracking games and the boys were looking forward to the knock-out stages of the league cup.Inconsistency probably cost Star a few more wins, but that’s what youth football development is all about and there is potential for the boys to develop.Well done from coaches and parents to the  boys who played this season – Craig Aitken, Zak Barclay, Gregor Brown, Keiran Caskie, Lewis Curran, Ruaridh Green, Woody Hoad, Alexander McLean, Conner McMurchy, Leon Murphy, Innes Paterson, Jamie Stewart and Tom West.Thanks for great support goes to sponsors Ardrishaig Community Trust, main strip, SC Crawford Building Contractors Limited, change strip and zip tops, Jewsons, tracksuits, and Mid Argyll Youth Development Services and the parents, supporters, referees and opposition teams that have made the season so enjoyable.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column june 12 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe selfish and reckless behaviour of many people visiting Argyll is to be deplored. They may think they are fine and the risk is minimal, but what about the thousand other folk with the same attitude near the same beauty spot This self-centred approach is also witnessed in the nature and volume of litter discarded. What goes through peoples# minds to leave their filth behind them The majority of bikers are fine # eventheir machines should still be in the garage # but the odd Power Ranger drags the biker name down. Think of the emergency services who will attendand when an accident happens.In contrast to the above, let#s spare a thought for the young men thrown in front of Hitler#s battle-hardened forces and Panzer tanks  years ago at St Valéry-en-Caux.The Argylls did rise again, fighting with distinction through Italy later in the war and in many other battles.But too many young Highlanders# lives were lost and changed forever in their valiant effort to stem the Nazi tide at St Valéry.Lest we forget.

title: letters to the editor june 12 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to take this opportunity to thank volunteers for all their help and hard work over the lockdown period.Volunteering groups have been amazing and I have personal experience of the support offered by Team Tarbert to enable others to stay safely at home.The volunteers have been compassionate and reassuring and every visit the volunteer has a cheery smile and happy wave.Thank you to all volunteers. You have made a dficult situation so much easier and it is much appreciated.Stay safe stay well.Councillor Anne Horn, Tarbert.Is it possible for the public toilet in Lochgilphead to be opened again soonthe necessary safety measures can be put in place to protect the public and staff I would suggest:I think the toilets should be available soon for the public, but more safety measures such as disinfectant hand spray would be required before they opened.Peter Laing, Lochgilphead.Dear Mr Laing,In order to focus resources on maintaining essential services, protecting frontline staff and ensuring public safety, a number of services have been suspended, including the closure of public conveniences.At this time, we do not have the resources to ensure public conveniences are regularly cleaned and maintained, furthermore we do not wish to encourage those from outlying areas to visit and risk bringing infection to the local area.We will continue to monitor the services and will re-open the public toilets when safe to do so.Sir,In condoning Dominic Cummings decision to go to Durham and Barnard Castle during lockdown, Boris Johnson has completely undermined trust in the UK Government and its efforts to control the spread of the deadly coronavirus.To trivialise his misdemeanours effectively says #it’s alright to disobey the rules#, #just follow your own instincts#. It shows contempt for those in the NHS who have risked their lives to save others. It shows contempt for those who have died without their loved ones by their side. It shows contempt for all of us who have stuck by the rules to protect our lives and the lives of others.Boris Johnson has asked us to #move on# but this issue will not go away. This is a wound that will continue to fester.Dominic Cummings continues to be a major player in government decisions and rules, those rules he so shamelessly flaunted without even an apology. He should have had the humility and integrity to resign, or been sacked by the Prime Minister.Marion Lacey, Lochgair.Sir,Organised by Scottish Land and Estates , the annual Helping it Happen Awards, which are free to enter, showcase the work done in   by businesses, farms and estates to help rural Scotland thrive.We have heard of so many wonderful examples of people working together during the COVID- pandemic, so we are especially encouraging entries to our new #Community Champion of the Year# category.If you have helped your community during the pandemic, ersied your business, are doing innovative work on your farm or perhaps you have been doing some really important work in conservation, the environment or educating youngsters about rural Scotland, you should enter # or nominate someone .The Helping it Happen Awards are sponsored by GLM and there will be a Community Champion of the Year award across five Scottish regions: North East, Highland, Central Scotland, South West and South East.To enter, visit tie SLE website or search for #Helping it Happen Awards# online. title: letters to the editor june 26 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In publishing the opinion piece #All lives matter# from your contributor on page  of the June  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, you have demonstrated a profound lack of understanding of the current Black Lives Matter protests.The tone-deaf piece is an attempt by your contributor to shut down engagement and perpetuate ignorance.How anybody can make the claim that all lives matter after witnessing such horric police brutality is beyond belief.All lives cannot matter until Black Lives Matter.Instead of deflecting and diluting the conversation, surely it is time to educate ourselves about what is happening, and to fight systemic injustice Madeleine Conn, ArdrishaigSir,The SNP continues to demonstrate its economic incompetence.New figures show the SNP government underspent its budget by a quarter of a billion pounds in -, and failed to use £ million of borrowing capacity. ​Instead of demanding further borrowing powers and more funding from the UK Government, the separatists should learn to use the resources they already have.With such colossal mismanagement, it#s no surprise that even senior SNP advisor Andrew Wilson has stated that Scotland is set to be the worst performing economy in the developed world. Once again, the separatists# numbers simply don#t add up.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands wardSir,Exactly two years ago I was diagnosed with stage three, oestrogen positive breast cancer.I’d just come back from a week#s holiday in Spain with Isabel and Margaret. Days before I went on holiday I’d had a biopsy following referral from my GP. Although there wasn’t a cloud in the sky, my holiday was definitely clouded by impending results#I had chosen to wait until after my holiday to get them.The journey that Monday to go to Gartnavel is one I’ll never forget. My partner Frank didn’t shut up the whole way there, obviously he was nervous. I couldn’t be bothered with the small talk and just wanted him to shut up. Obviously I was nervous and he was just trying to keep my mind off it, but I was too busy silently praying. The number  is something I see all the time so I spent the whole journey looking for the number on someone’s licence plate #I saw it everything would be ok. I didn#t see it. That might sound a bit daft, but fear does crazy things to you.Walking into the consultant#s room and finding a nurse waiting there confirmed my worst fears. #It’s a wee cancer,# said Mr Wilson. The words echoing in my head, I couldn’t hear anything after that. I remember taking a deep breath and looking at Frank. I will never, ever forget the look on his face.My only question that day was #am I going to lose my breasts # The answer was no, and thankfully Frank was there to take in what was being said my head was spinning. The question I really wanted to ask was #am I going to die # I was too scared to ask that question.I didn’t cry until I walked out the hospital, then I bawled. Frank was amazing, and he didn’t talk like a budgie on the way home.The journey home was horrendous. I was terried about telling my mum. How do you tell your mum that her only child has cancer  I hadn’t told her anything about finding a lump. I couldn’t cope with worrying about her worrying about me # butit happens again I#d do it dferently and she’ll be the first to know. By the time I got home I had no more tears left.The relief telling mum was a huge weight off my shoulders. What ensued after my initial diagnosis was two weeks of crying every day. Telling the girls at work was so emotional, and in fact I was exhausted with it all.Once surgery and treatment plans were in place I was in a better place. Time to get the head down and get on with it, and that#s what I did. I was full of positivity and determination, and I think my sense of humour helped enormously.The treatment was bad, but it was necessary. The ongoing treatment is bad but it#s necessary. I’m alive and that’s what matters. My le has changed forever, nothing will be the same. My le has been ided into Before Cancer and After Cancer  I now have a new #normal#.I don’t know what the future holds, who does, but I intend to live my le happily, positively and most definitely to the fullest!I will never forget the support, both physically and emotionally that I received from my nearest and dearest, and of course from the whole community. The strength you have given me continues, and for that I am truly grateful.Please, pleaseyou find an abnormality or you just feel something isn’t quite right, act upon it and seek attention.I know it’s a dficult time with this horrid virus but it’s important to remember that early detection saves lives.Stay safe and take care.Yvie Young, Lochgilphead

title: wealth of shinty pictures uncovered in furnace
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA treasure trove of old shinty photos has been unearthed in Furnace after lying in a suitcase for decades.The photograph collection belonged to former Furnace and Lochfyneside player, the late Niven #Bunty# Crawford, and turned up earlier this month when his daughter Christine Crawford was having a lockdown clearout.Christine#s nephew and Bunty Crawford#s grandson Scott Robertson told the Advertiser his grandfather#s story.Bunty Crawford was born and raised in Minard.Just before the Second World War he was taking a course at Glasgow University School of Art # and was in demand as a shinty player. While in the city he played for the university, and in fact played in the   Littlejohn Vase final.He joined the Royal Naval Reserve and on the outbreak of war was posted to the Royal Navy destroyer HMS Icarus. Aboard the Icarus, he saw action in the Norwegian campaign, including the the Battle of Narvik, during  and was involved in the Dunkirk evacuation.After the war Bunty ed to finish his university qualication, and married ChristinaMacCallum from Furnace in .Bunty and his young we settled in Furnace where they had three children, John, Moira and Christine. He turned out in goals for Lochfyneside shinty team, playing in the  and  Camanachd Cup finals # losing out to Newtonmore on both occasions.Lochfyneside disbanded in the s and reverted to the old Furnace club. It was at that point Bunty, a painter and decorator, stepped back from playing. He continued to follow shinty over the years often accompanied his friend, neighbour, fellow war veteran and Lochfyneside team-mate Jimmy Sinclair.Bunty was a keen photographer and recorded many matches and occasions which would otherwise have been left to the memories of the people who were there. He also captured priceless images of shinty characters now long gone but fondly remembered.He died in  at the age of .Scott himself has been a stalwart of Inveraray Shinty Club for three decades and a member of the team, along with his brother David, which lted the Camanachd Cup in .Hid grandfather would have been proud of the boys # but maybe less so about the team they were playing for. #My grandpa and Jimmy were staunch Furnace men, and there was always this Furnace Inveraray rivalry,# Scott explained.#He always said to me never to join Inveraray, and after he died, my gran carried it on.#When I was  or  I ended up playing for Inveraray, but he was dyed-in-the-wool Furnace through and through. He would be turning in his grave..!#He added: #It#s great to have these photos, and I have sent a lot of them to the Shinty Memories Facebook page, which uses memories to help folk living with issues such as dementia and isolation.#Hopefully people will enjoy seeing them.#

title: letters to the editor july 3 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Communities on the A are blighted by the noise of bikers, many with illegal exhausts.Inveraray is the gathering point for motorcyclists and on a recent Saturday during lockdown around  were gathered, not two metre social distancing, and failing to adhere to the maximum eight in a group guidance.This has become the norm throughout the summer, and it seems lockdown guidance does not apply to bikers as they have been a constant feature on the roads, even in phase one.The unofficial Argyll TT goes past our homes most weekends over the spring and summer months.I have a bike licence and understand the feeling of freedom, but three-figure speeds past residential entrances, many of them hidden, is completely unacceptable.As a resident you begin to dread the weekend and sunny days. The noise is constant and intrusive for  –  hours in a day, the decibel level in excess of  dB where sounds above  dB are harmful to hearing.This is a serious issue for residents who cannot open their doors and windows, cannot use their gardens, pets are terried, it is often impossible to have a conversation, or a phone call. The noise from hundreds of bikes is explosive and destructive.The speeds are terrying, they travel in intimidating packs, the noise is threatening and the bikers have no respect for the communities they are speeding through. They pass multiple residential entrances with limited sight lines with no care for risk. The offensive noise seems to come from two actions modying motorbike exhausts and extreme acceleration in legal bikes.If a car made a similar noise, spewed out the same polluting omissions, or did the same ridiculous speeds they would be pulled over by the police, but bikers appear above the law.As technology reduces the noise pollution of cars, planes and other forms of transport, it seems motorbikes are exempt. Bikers claim #loud pipes save lives# but is safety really the motivation for deliberately creating excessive noise Noise counts as a statutory nuisance it either unreasaonably and substantially interferes with the user or enjoyment of a home or other premises or is likely to injure health.The problem on A is known to all the statutory agencies, but nothing is done.If this is a national problem, what action needs to be taken Concerned Loch Fyne-side resident Sir,I am not qualied to judge economic competence, but considering the party he represents, I think that Councillor Redman might find it advisable to be wary of the phrase #colossal mismanagement# .For my part, I would consider a degree of incompetence to be preferable to the great damage caused over the last decade to  per cent of the UK’s people, as well as to its institutions and its reputation by the cruel, self-serving, xenophobic, elitist, dishonestregime currently in Westminster.Name supplied, LochgilpheadSir,Our charity#s support for blind and partially sighted people affected by the coronavirus lockdown has received a £, boost from the Scottish Government#s Wellbeing Fund.With this extra funding we will be able to support an additional  people and respond to the increased demand for more in-depth, one-to-one emotional support.The practical and psychological effects of losing your sight can have a signicant impact on people’s well-being, and this current situation has exacerbated the anxiety and isolation felt by many.Access to essential services such as food and medicines is more dficult as is social distancing, vital information on staying safe isn#t always in accessible formats, and many of our older members aren#t always confident about using new technology to stay in touch with others.Everyone accessing RNIB#s confidential counselling service will receive eight weekly sessions with an accredited counsellor, delivered via telephone and online, with each session normally lasting an hour.The funding will enable us to reduce the waiting list for emergency mental health sessions and also let existing clients access additional sessions.The RNIB helpline is available on   .James Adams, RNIB Scotland directorSir,Every pub across Scotland should be allowed to stock and sell beer from local independent brewers, to help them recover post-lockdown.CAMRA, the Campaign for Real Ale has launched the #Cheers for Choice# campaign.The campaign wants these arrangements to be relaxed, and MSPs are also being urged to support the Tied Pubs Bill being put forward in the Scottish Parliament by Labour MSP Neil Bibby. The legislation would give tied pub tenants protections in law, including a right to be able to sell guest beers in their pubs.Allowing small and independent brewers to sell into all pubs will also improve consumer choice and allow pub-goers to support local brewing businesses.It also makes business sense, with  per cent of pub-goers saying they would be less likely to go back to a pubit doesn’t have a range of brews from small and independent producers.Sarah Crawford, CAMRA Director for Scotland, Kirkcaldy

title: could a two way conversation transform scotlands health
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSome of us have learned in lockdown the importance of other people, and have been longing for these first personal contacts.There have been surprises in discovering just what is important in le, and the comfort of knowing you are not alone in your likes, as your favourite brand of chocolate is again sold out.We have also been made aware that the way we behave makes a dference to the future. It has taken a national emergency to get the government to acknowledge that it needs our compliance and, for that, must give us the information we need.Suddenly the choices we make are seen as vitally important, and we have a part to play in achieving success for ourselves and our community. Can this be a foundation for a future partnership that could transform the health of Scotland and the pressure on our services As a physiotherapist I became aware that there was little that one could do to impose solutions there had to be a relationship that involved two way listening, mutual trust and support to do what was necessary. In this pandemic Nicola Sturgeon has said that we have behaved in a way that saved lives and protected the NHS.When this is over we could be at the beginning of another le-altering journey.It will demand a huge sht in expectations. There is an amazing bias in society towards the idea of decrepitude and dependency in old age, when in fact encouraging dependency increases a slide into that very state. During past months many of these attitudes have been exposed and caused outrage but they are long standing and deep seated.If you have been trying to escape into fiction you might have no better idea of what is possible. Alison Flood interviewed crime writers about their work, and this is what she found.Ian Rankin is now writing about a John Rebus who has health issues, James Lee Burke has his detective Robicheaux meditating on mortality in his early s and Mark Billingham has slowed his Tom Thorne down a bit because he is in his s. Michael Connelly does not believe that it is credible to have his Harry Bosch with a badge and gun and still working for the LAPD, this in a country where the President is  and one of the presidential hopefuls .Worst of all, Sara Paretsky created a feisty, strong woman for her books, only to succumb to popular misconceptions and stop her age at  because she didn#t #want Vi to be helpless#.These fictional creations battle the evils they see in their society. Now that it is realised how our inidual decision making makes a dference, whatever our age, we have no need to feel helpless.It is time to ask for the information and support we need.

title: small but mighty navy boats deployed off west coast
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThree of the Royal Navy’s P Archer class patrol boats have been visiting the west coast of Scotland as part of their summer deployment.The ships – HMS Biter, HMS Charger and HMS Express – support University Royal Naval Unitsand are spending a fortnight training on the west coast of Scotland.Between July  and July  the vessels will stop off at ious harbours and lochs between conducting waterborne training where they will practice maritime skills.Captain Chris Smith, naval regional commander for Scotland and Northern Ireland, said: #The Ps may be small, but they pack a punch and regularly exercise around the UK and Europe as well as supporting the fleet.#Usually we would be hosting visits from local groups and organisations, but, with the current situation, this is unfortunately not possible. We still hope to engage with local organisations across social media and using new technologies, however, andpeople spot the ships in their area please do give them a wave!#Each of the vessels is affiliated to universities around the country and has a core crew of full-time Royal Navy sailors, which in normal times would be augmented by members of the University Royal Naval Units . As this is not possible this time due to the current restrictions, each vessel will use new technologies to have a weekly virtual drill night with their associated URNU.At just over  metres long, the Ps are some of the smallest ships in the fleet and perfect for navigation and seamanship training. It also means they can access smaller harbours which, because of their size, usually can’t host Royal Navy ships.The Royal Navy has  Fast Inshore Patrol Craft which together form the First Patrol Boat Squadron.Although their primary role is to support the URNUs, two of them, HMS Tracker and HMS Raider, are permanently based at HMNB Clyde where they are part of the team safeguarding the nuclear fleet.At the same time as Biter, Charger and Express undertake their west coast deployment, four boats # Trumpeter, Archer, Explorer and Example # will sail up Scotland#s east coast.The three ships will be at Port Ellen from July  to , Oban from July  to  and Fort William from July  to . Further ports of call are planned, including Kyle of Lochalsh, Ullapool, Stornoway, Lochboisdale and Tobermory, with dates to be confirmed.PIC:Four Archer class P patrol boats together at sea. no_aNavyPatrolBoats
